Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Wireless Design for Fast M2M Control

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to explore the fundamental architectural considerations involved in designing/operating wireless networks for fast Machine to Machine (M2M) communication. Current ideas in the M2M space are fundamentally being driven by ``slow M2M'' applications like electricity-monitoring in the Smart Grid with their intellectual foundations coming from the now maturing field of wireless sensor networks. This project advances the field by addressing the high-performance case of industrial automation with tight real-time operating requirements and the demand for very high reliability. To do this, the project will be leveraging new mathematical and conceptual tools developed to understand decentralized control systems as well as modern approaches to doing multiterminal wireless networking that better exploit the full potential of the wireless medium. The techniques used in this project will span networking, control theory, information theory, wireless modeling, signal processing, and circuit implementation.

Broadly speaking, the kind of "Fast M2M" technology that this project is developing has the potential to help invigorate the agile manufacturing sector of the economy. Easily reconfigurable wireless interconnection in the industrial setting could help high-skill manufacturing where the United States has a potential advantage over low-wage countries. In the course of developing this technology, the project will train students and postdocs in a way that encourages cross-fertilization of ideas between wireless communication, networking, circuit implementation, control theory, and information theory. These ideas will also be incorporated into courses, including new M.Eng. courses aimed at educating technical leaders for industry. This is the kind of non-siloed education that is essential for innovation in the future. The project will also broaden participation in the technical workforce by mentoring female graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, our intellectual goals were to unify control with wireless communication. This is very important for the world and the United States in particular as we move towards a world of increasingly autonomous systems. These machines need to interact with each other, and wireless communication is a natural way for them to do so. Unfortunately, existing understandings of wireless communication were focused on moderate reliability (this is why everyone has experienced dropped cellphone calls and flaky WiFi) with a focus on high data rate. Existing control systems largely rely on wired links to interact --- for example industrial machinery used in manufacturing. Understanding how to do this wirelessly could unlock a great deal of innovation, which would benefit the USA economy and create jobs.

However, to do this, we needed to have a way to unify control with wireless. Traditionally, these grew from very different roots and modeling philosophies. However, we found that they could indeed be brought closer. In particular, we were able to come up with a way to quantify the impact of uncertainty and unreliability in control actuation, using the language of information theory. This is the same mathematical language that underpins communication. This was the idea of "control capacity." 

Furthermore, we were able to figure out the broad outlines of how we could achieve very reliable communication with very short latencies using wireless communication. The key was to bring in the attitude towards uncertainty that we find in control theory --- namely that all models are only approximately correct but we need to function robustly despite those uncertainties. This requires understanding what it is that we can truly count on. In the case of wireless communication, we need to count on diversity. 

One of the important goals of the NSF, and one of the reasons that the USA's higher education system stays cutting edge, is to unify research with teaching. In our case, we moved towards bringing the heart of these lofty ideas to the level of freshmen. This required understanding what the essence was --- and we found that the essential heart of understanding uncertainty and control could be expressed linear algebraically. Furthermore, this could be made accessible to freshmen with a newly designed course sequence that teaches students linear algebra as something that abstracts real world issues and allows us to get penetrating insight. 

Finally, this project was also about training people and growing our skilled workforce. Multiple graduate students and undergraduate students grew into more productive scholars by working on these challenging problems.
